keyTakeAways: Paul Ingrassia, a nominee for the Office of Special Counsel (OSC), withdrew from the nomination after reports emerged of racist text messages allegedly sent by him to a Republican group chat.
The messages included claims that Martin Luther King Jr. Day should be 'tossed into the seventh circle of hell' and that Ingrassia has a 'Nazi streak,' prompting ethical and political concerns.
Ingrassia’s nomination had already faced scrutiny due to past inflammatory statements, conspiracy theories, and support for White nationalist figures and anti-Israel rhetoric.
The White House and Senate Majority Leader John Thune indicated the nomination would be withdrawn due to lack of bipartisan support and concerns over antisemitism and racism.
The Zionist Organization of America, a major Jewish group that had previously backed Ingrassia, withdrew its support after the text messages were reported, citing the need to combat antisemitism.
Republican Senator Rick Scott opposed the nomination from the outset, and one of the key factors in its collapse was the loss of support from influential community groups.
Ingrassia’s nomination was seen as a departure from the traditionally independent and impartial role of the OSC, given his close loyalty to President Trump and history of controversial rhetoric.

His withdrawal underscores the growing scrutiny of political loyalty and past behavior in federal appointments, especially for positions involving whistleblower protection and civil service integrity.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Paul Ingrassia, a nominee for the Office of Special Counsel (OSC), withdrew his nomination after reports surfaced of racist text messages in which he allegedly referred to Martin Luther King Jr. Day as being 'tossed into the seventh circle of hell' and claimed he has a 'Nazi streak.' The revelations prompted the withdrawal of support from the Zionist Organization of America and led to opposition from Republican Senator Rick Scott. Senate Majority Leader John Thune indicated that the White House would pull the nomination, citing lack of bipartisan support and ethical concerns. Ingrassia, who has a history of promoting conspiracy theories, anti-Israel rhetoric, and White nationalist views, was seen as a politically loyal figure with a controversial past, diverging from the independent and impartial nature of the OSC. His withdrawal reflects growing scrutiny of political loyalty and past behavior in federal appointments, especially in positions safeguarding whistleblower protections.
title: Trump’s nominee for whistleblower office is withdrawn after reports of racist texts
